Feedback

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para:
The &applet; applet provides a command line that you can use within any panel on the desktop. To add &applet; to a panel right-click on the panel to open the Panel menu, then choose
Add to panel Utility &applet; .

&applet; contains the following interactive elements:
Entry field
You can enter commands, macros, and programs in the Entry field..
Browser button
You can use the Browser button to look through your file system for programs. A solid circle icon identifies the Browser button.
History button
You can use the History button to recall previous commands. A down-arrow icon identifies the History button.
&applet; provides the following features:
History list of previously executed commands
You can execute commands directly from the history list display. You can also cycle the history list contents through the entry field to display and then execute a command. If you remove &applet; from a panel then add the applet to any panel later in the session, the history list retains all previous commands. A vertical scrollbar appears when more than 20 commands are in the history list.
History-based autocompletion function
&applet; uses the history-based autocompletion function to complete commands in the entry field. This function compares the contents of the entry field with the history list. If &applet; finds a match then the applet completes the command.
User-requestable command completion function
This command completion function compares character strings in the entry field with commands in the user path. The command completion function is useful if you do not know the exact character sequence or spelling of a command. After you type the first few letters of the command name, press the Tab key. If &applet; recognizes the character sequence as unique, then the applet completes the command name.
Macro facility
The macro facility provides up to 99 short-cut commands. In addition to predefined commands you can create your own commands for use with &applet;.

sect1.title: Usage
sect1.para:
You can use &applet; to perform the following actions:
To run a command from the entry field.
To run a macro from the entry field.
To run a program from your file system.
To run a previous command, macro, or program from the history list.

sect2.title: To Run a Command From the Entry Field
sect2.para: To run a command from the entry field, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Type the command in the entry field.
If you want, you can instruct Mini-Commander to try to complete the command name. Press the Tab key to give this instruction.
Type any options that you want to run with the command in the entry field.

sect2.para: If the Enable history based autocompletion option is selected then during steps 1 to 3 &applet; searches for a match in the history list. If there is a match in the history list, then &applet; completes the command. If you want to accept the command, then press Return. Alternatively, if you do not want to accept the command then type more characters in the entry field.

sect2.title: To Run a Macro From the Entry Field
sect2.para: To run a macro that is defined in the &applet; Macros list, type the macro in the entry field and press Return.
The history based autocompletion function also works for macros.
The following list shows some examples of &applet; macros:

entry.para: Starts a Netscape browser displaying a dictionary search page.

sect2.title: To Run a Program From Your File System
sect2.para: Click on the Browser button to display the file system, then double click on the program you want to run.
You can use &applet; to run scripts, executable files, or other programs from your file system.

sect2.title: To Run a Previous Command, Macro, or Program From the History List
sect2.para:
You can run a previously executed command, macro, or program from the history list in one of the following ways:
Click on the History button to display the history list. Click on a history list item to run the command, macro, or program that you require.
Click on the entry field, then use the keyboard up and down arrows to cycle through the history list. Press Return to run a specific command, macro, or program when the history list item you want is displayed in the entry field.

sect1.title: Settings
sect1.para: To configure &applet;, right-click on an area of the applet outside the interactive elements, then choose Properties from the popup menu.
The Properties dialog contains the following tabbed sections:

sect2.title: General
sect2.para: Select this option to display the time in the lower part of the applet.
Default: selected.
Select this option to display the date in the lower part of the applet.
Default: unselected.
Select this option to attach a handle to the edge of the applet. You can use the handle to drag the &applet; display to any location on your desktop.
Default: unselected.
Select this option to show a frame around the &applet;.
Default: selected.
Select this option to instruct &applet; to compare the entry field with the history list, and complete commands when there is a match.
Default: selected.
Use this text box to specify the applet width in pixels.
Default: 148 pixels.
Use this text box to specify the applet height in pixels.
Default: 48 pixels.
Use this text box to specify the height of the entry field in pixels.
Default: 24 pixels.
Click on this button to display a color selection dialog for the command line text.
Default: light gray.
Click on this button to display a color selection dialog for the entry field background.
Default: black.

sect2.title: Macros
sect2.para:
This tabbed section contains a list of macros that you can use with &applet;. The list contains the following columns:
A list of UNIX regular expressions in the left column.
A regular expression is a pattern of characters or numbers that you use to match strings. See the regex man page for further information on how to construct a regular expression.
A list of macros in the right column.
A macro executes if the corresponding regular expression successfully matches the command that you type into the &applet; entry field. The macros are commands that can take parameters parsed by the regular expression.
You can add or modify any of the regular expressions or macros.
